name: 杭學鳴
objective: This course introduces fundamental concepts, algorithms and applications in digital signal processing. Starting from a description of how signals can be represented as digital waveforms and how systems may be modeled as digital filters, the course investigates the processing and analysis of signals using the most common approaches and algorithms. It covers signal representation and Fourier transform, sampling theorem, discrete-time sys-tem representation and analysis, and FIR and IIR digital filter analysis and design.
schedule:
1.　　Introduction (Chap. 1 of textbook)
2.　　Sinusoids (Chap. 2)
3.　　Spectrum representation (Chap. 3)
4.　　Sampling and aliasing (Chap. 4)
5.　　FIR filters (Chap. 5)
6.　　Frequency response of FIR filters (Chap. 6)
7.　　z-transform (Chap. 7)
8.　　IIR filters (Chap. 8)
scorePolicy:
6-7 Homework + 3-4 Computer Assignment (Matlab)    15%
2 Quizzes  (1 hour, 12.5% each, closed book)      25%
Midterm Exam  (closed book)                 25%
Final Exam　　(closed book)                    35%
materials:
Textbook: J.H. McClellan, R.W. Schafer, M.A. Yoder, Signal Processing First, Prentice Hall, 2003.
Recommended Readings:
(1)　　A.V. Oppenheim and R.W. Schafer, Discrete-Time Signal Processing, 2nd Ed., Prentice-Hall, 1999.
(2)　　R.G. Lyons, Understanding Digital Signal Processing, 2nd Ed., Prentice-Hall, 2004.
(3)　　Steven W. Smith, The Scientist and Engineer's Guide to Digital Signal Processing, http://www.dspguide.com/.
